intro: Stoebe rosea, commonly known as pink puccoon, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to North America. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its upright, branched stems and hairy leaves. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers in late spring to early summer, which are clustered in dense, terminal inflorescences. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a rough texture, while its roots are thick and fleshy. Stoebe rosea is adapted to a variety of soil types and is often found in open woods, fields, and along roadsides.
